docs.lead_paragraph: Swinging his car out to pass on a country road in South America, Javier Mozo found himself in the path of a roaring, smoke-belching cross-country bus. Swerving off the road, the car flipped and rolled. Somehow, Javier crawled out of the wreckage alive. But his brother Ernesto was not so lucky. He died in Javier's arms. Or at least that is what Ernesto's wife, Maria Magdalena Santos, and Javier Mozo told the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company, which had insured Ernesto Mozo's life for $500,000.

headline.main: Fake Deaths Abroad Are a Growing Problem for Insurers

docs.abstract: American insurance companies say they increasingly are victims of schemes in which life insurance policyholders fake their own deaths; in most fraud cases, central thread is a trip abroad, preferably to some place trying to cope with an upheaval; more and more residents of US have ties to developing countries, where it is easier to fake deaths; as American insurance companies extend their global reach, they are aggressively selling policies in countries with less rigorous standards for record-keeping and documentation; case involving Ernesto Mozo, who allegedly died in car crash, but in fact is very much alive, detailed; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Swinging his car out to pass on a country road in South America, Javier Mozo found himself in the path of a roaring, smoke-belching cross-country bus. Swerving off the road, the car flipped and rolled. Somehow, Javier crawled out of the wreckage...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first large organized backlash against what they call the industrialization of medicine, many doctors of Massachusetts' renowned medical schools and teaching hospitals are calling for a moratorium on corporate takeovers of health services and for curbs on the companies' intrusion into doctors' decision-making. ''It's time to put a stop to it,'' said Dr. Bernard Lown, 76, who, as chairman of the Ad Hoc Committee to Defend Health Care, is organizing the campaign.

headline.main: Doctors Organize to Fight Corporate Intrusion

docs.abstract: Many doctors in renowned medical schools and teaching hospitals in Massachusetts, in first organized backlash against what they say is industrialization of medicine, are calling for moratorium on corporate takeovers of health services and for curbs on companies' intrusion into doctors' decision-making; some comment; photos (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Inevitable Surgery on Medicare'' (editorial, June 26) holds that Medicare will be rescued by changing the eligibility age and increasing contributions by the wealthy. Absolutely, but not according to plans crafted by the Senate.

headline.main: Now Use Medicare for Universal Coverage

docs.abstract: Prof Anne-Emanuelle Birn letter disputes June 26 editorial, which argued that Medicare could be rescued by changing eligibility age and increasing contributions by wealthy (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Inevitable Surgery on Medicare'' (editorial, June 26) holds that Medicare will be rescued by changing the eligibility age and increasing contributions by the wealthy. Absolutely, but not according to plans crafted by the Senate.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Inevitable Surgery on Medicare'' (editorial, June 26) says that ''when Congress voted in 1988 to raise Medicare premiums on wealthier retirees, the elderly forced it to repeal the decision.'' In fact, Medicare premiums were raised for all beneficiaries without regard to income. In addition, a surtax was to be levied on income taxes paid by elderly people of moderate or high income; it was the country's first tax on age.

headline.kicker: Now Use Medicare for Universal Coverage

docs.abstract: John L Hess letter disputes JUne 26 editorial on Medicare, which suggests system could be saved by changing eligibility age and increasing contributions by wealthy (S)
